div.p: German concert pianist, teacher, editor, and writer on music.

div.head: Career Summary
div.p: From 1860, Reinecke was professor of piano at the Leipzig Conservatory, of which he became the Director in 1897. Reinecke was a prolific composer, edited keyboard concertos, and was author of several books and many articles.

div.head: Reinecke and Schenker
div.p: Schenker disagreed with Reinecke's readings in editions, generally citing his name along with others, as in the following statement: "It is imperative for me by these means at long last to eradicate existing preconceptions that have unfortunately been propagated even by such musicians as, e.g., BÃ¼low, Reinecke, Busoni, etc." (letter to Emil Hertzka, WSLB 69/71, November 1, 1910). Schenker criticizes Reinecke's Die Beethoven'sche Clavier-Sonaten (Leipzig, 1873, 9/1924--of which there was a copy in Schenker's personal library) in his essay on Beethoven Op. 2, No. 1 ( Der Tonwille, Heft 2 (1922), p. 48; Eng. trans., vol. I, pp. 94-95).
